content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is recognized for its unspoiled areas, excellent water quality, historic landscapes, and significant structures. The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia includes mill villages, parks, historic districts, and landmarks like Stallings Island and Meadow Garden. The area offers beautiful rural landscapes, scenic vistas, and recreational opportunities. The Augusta Canal and related mill sites represent the development of the cotton textile industry in the South, leading to the transformation of the agrarian economy into an early industrial economy. Several significant sites in the area are associated with various historical events and diverse cultural groups. The Augusta Canal area, encompassing Revolution, the Civil War, Native Americans, Colonial Americans, African Americans, Chinese Americans, and Irish Americans, is at risk of losing its cultural, historical, natural, and recreational resources without Federal Government assistance. The Secretary of the Interior has designated it a priority for protection. The Augusta Canal National Historic Landmark is considered threatened and a priority for protection by the Secretary of the Interior. Local, regional, and State agencies, businesses, and private citizens are eager to work together to preserve and enhance the resources of the landmark. The purpose of this Act is to establish a cooperative management framework for the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area in Georgia, aiming to preserve its significant features while promoting economic development. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area is established in Georgia and includes lands in Georgia and South Carolina known as the Augusta Canal. The purpose is to preserve significant features and promote economic development. The Secretary of the Interior will publish a detailed description and map of the boundaries for the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area in the Federal Register. The Augusta Canal Commission is established. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including five from the Augusta Canal Authority, one from the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, and one from the Georgia congressional delegation. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Georgia congressional delegation, the Governor of Georgia, and the Governor of South Carolina. The Commission elects a chairman from its members, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Georgia congressional delegation, the Governor of Georgia, and the Governor of South Carolina. The Commission elects a chairman from its members, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Augusta Canal Commission must prepare a management plan for the Heritage Area within a year of this Act's enactment. The plan should integrate Federal, State, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, to protect and enhance the area's cultural, natural, scenic, and recreational resources. The Secretary is authorized to provide technical and financial assistance for the preparation of the management plan, which must be approved or disapproved within 180 days of submission. The approval criteria include considering the strength of local planning in the area. In approving a plan, the Secretary considers local support, economic impact, partnership potential, and property rights infringement. The Secretary considers local support, economic impact, partnership potential, and property rights infringement when approving a plan. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary notifies the Augusta Canal Commission in writing, providing reasons for disapproval and recommendations for revision. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 180 days of receipt. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan and the Commission must continue revising and resubmitting until approval is granted. Upon approval of the management plan, the Secretary and the Augusta Canal Commission will implement it through cooperative agreements with relevant entities. The Augusta Canal Commission and relevant entities will implement the management plan for economic development in the area. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those in place before its establishment. No Federal agency can introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the Heritage Area's designation. SEC. 7. Duties of other Federal entities include consulting, cooperating, and coordinating activities with the Secretary and Augusta Canal Commission to prevent adverse effects on the Heritage Area. SEC. 8.
